text: My name is Segev Tsfuti. I'm Director of Academic Programs here at the Stanford Center for Professional Development
and I'm really excited to have you here tonight. We have gathered a very interesting group of people to share information with you,
and we'll start by just taking. This and then getting started.
So I want to acknowledge all the SCPD team members who are working with colleagues and other teams across the university with a single purpose in mind,
and that is to give you access to these classes that are offered every quarter here at Stanford.
The result this autumn quarter, SCPD is offering 64 classes to remote students,
and we're excited to have you here and join us. As you look around the room, and as you get to know your classmates later in the welcome reception,
also know that you are part of a group of more than 1,100 remote students that are joining you this quarter from around the world and all over the country.
[NOISE] So, on behalf of all of us at Stanford, congratulation on taking this step
in your education journey, we're really glad you're here. Our goal tonight is to share with you
the information need to know to get the quarter off to a good start. Our discussion will be mostly Q and A with a panel of experts,
two returning SCPD students, a professor, and a TA. All of whom will tell it to you simply just the way it is.
[NOISE] But before we dive in, I want to introduce our keynote speaker tonight,
Computer Science Professor, John Mitchell. John earned his Bachelor's degree at Stanford and his Masters and PhD degrees at MIT.
He joined Stanford as a professor in 1988 and over the years, has published hundreds of articles and
collaborations and taught and advised thousands of students. John's first research project in online education,
started in 2009 when he and six undergraduate students built Stanford Courseware,
an innovative platform that expanded to support interactive video and discussion. Courseware served as a foundation for initial flipped classroom experiments at
Stanford and helped inspire  the first massive open online courses better known as MOOCs,
from Stanford, that captured worldwide attention in 2011. Since 2012, John has served as vice provost at Stanford.
Most recently, as the vice provost for teaching and learning. Under John's leadership, SCPD transitioned
from the School of Engineering to a unit within VPTL, allowing SCPD to have a broader impact and reach across the entire university.
After completing two terms as Vice Provost, John stepped down earlier this year but before
we started missing him too bad and for real, we were happy to learn that in
January he will become chair of the Computer Science Department, by far our largest collaboration in the university.
So, while he's no longer my boss's boss's boss, [LAUGHTER] I'm still working for him.
So, with this in mind, please help me and give John Mitchell an SCPD welcome.
[APPLAUSE] Thank you, John.
Thank you, Segev. So, I just want to welcome you all here and congratulate you on making the excellent choice to
listen to people like me and believe what we say and [LAUGHTER] go off and tell other people because it's all true and we wouldn't teach you anything if we didn't know it well here.
So, I think this program here has been very successful. Many of you may not know much about the history.
Apparently, in the School of Engineering, our distance education programs date back to 1954.
So, that's before I was born. I have no idea what they did in 1954,
[NOISE] probably something on paper in the mail or something like that. I don't know how they did distance education in 1954.
I know in the 1970s, we had this kind of direct, microwave TV link to local companies.
Hewlett-Packard was one of the leading companies, in the Valley at that time. Other companies would subscribe.
And I was actually a student here, as Segev mentioned, some time in that decade,
and what I remember from a course that I took in this building, just right above this auditorium,
is we would all sit in the classroom and look at our little screens and the person at the front would talk at his little screen.
And whenever there was a question, somebody else in the valley could push their button at their site in Milpitas
or Cupertino or someplace else in Palo Alto and ask a question in real time.
So, the quality of some things has gone up but we've kind of lost that interactive and I- interaction with
you if you're remote- and I hope it'll come back some time in the time that you're involved in this program.
I'm not quite sure about that, but I really liked that interactive activity and I think that's something,
we can hope for in the future. Since the 1990s, this has been a web-based delivery,
which has been very successful. So, we, as Segev mentioned,
offer about 200 courses a year from the School of Engineering and otherwise in the format that you're
taking them and that's if you were to count the number of students enrolled on campus and where they're enrolled in.
That's the bulk of the student course hours in the school of engineering, are all available to all of you.
So, I think that's really represents our commitment at Stanford to reaching as many people as possible,
as successfully as we can, and you all look bright and cheerful and energetic and so I'm sure we're reaching,
the right people as best we can there. One thing you might not know is that you probably have
the same experience remotely as students on campus. It turns out that about 80 percent of the video views for the courses that we,
deliver in the form that you see them, are from students on campus.
So, you might not see it remotely but for most of us teaching the room is empty [LAUGHTER] and everybody is remote.
[LAUGHTER] So, you are following the most popular path through Stanford [LAUGHTER] by being remote students.
You're in really good company. I don't know if you've been to the Huang Engineering building,
does anybody recognize that? It's the place where there's a cafe and stuff just over behind this building.
Jen-Hsen Huang who was the donor, who is- the building is named after was a remote student.
He got a master's student at Stanford and as far as I know, he never set foot on campus,
during that time. So, you're on the path to become CEO of a company like Nvidia if you want [LAUGHTER] and if you're lucky.
A friend of mine, Bill Dowly who used to teach in our department, has been the chief scientist
of Nvidia for maybe 10 years. And [NOISE] he told me an entertaining story that I'm
not gonna repeat about Jen- Hsen Huang being pulled over by the California Highway Patrol for driving his Ferrari too fast,
down the highway. So, I wish you success.
If you have that kind of success, don't tell us but if you have another kind of technical success around your business or
your scientific career, we love to hear about  it. The way you drive your Ferrari is kind of your business.
So, please enjoy the courses. I know that they're challenging. We try to challenge everyone.
That's what we do for a living. [LAUGHTER] But work hard, you know,
have fun, learn stuff and, you know, keep in touch. You know, let us know when something is successful when something isn't.
One of the things that I really appreciate very much and it happens all too infrequently,
is, you know, somebody, a year, five years, 10 years after they took a course,
will send me an email and say, you know that course I hated when I was a student?
Meaning my good course, you know, [LAUGHTER] it actually was very valuable and the most important part to
me was this and I didn't appreciate it at the time but now I do. You know, that kind of thing is very gratifying as a teacher.
We teach to, you know, this big empty room and lots of people on video. So, hearing from you is valuable to all of
us and I know as you go forward in your careers and have the success in the directions you choose, you know,
your advice and input to us on what we could do better or what topics we should cover or how we'd been helpful to you
is very valuable to us. So please, you know, make good connections with each other,
with other people in the courses and programs [NOISE] you enroll in and,
you know, keep us informed [NOISE] of what happens to you and where
we've been helpful to you and how we could be more, successful in reaching others.
So that's basically my thought. I don't know if there are any questions but
I do appreciate all of your interest in our programs. We work hard. As Segev has said,
there's a big organization here to try to deliver to you the best possible experience we can for people at a distance.
And from a point of view of being on the faculty here, we feel very enthusiastic about our fields.
We love our work, we love our topic area, and we're really just very pleased to be
able to share that with as many people as possible. So, please have a good evening here. Enjoy meeting each other and
thank you for coming [APPLAUSE]
Perfect. Thank you, John. Let me share with you the plan for the evening. First, I'm going to briefly overview some
of the key information you need to know as the quarter begins. Because all of this information is available online,
I'm not going to go into a lot of details about it. It's on our website,
the SCPD website or the university website, right? I do recommend that if anything I speak to is something that's is confusing,
not familiar or new, please be sure to ask questions of our team
later tonight and as we go to our network receptions, we wanna make sure that you have the right information.
So, after going over the short deck, we're- we'll introduce our panel team members,
we'll respond to your questions. Now, this is really cool and this is our first time trying it but it's been tested here. So let's give it a try.
I'm going to ask you to go to pollev.com/scpd, on your phone.
And start, you have the choice to enter an input, a question that you'd like to ask the panel.
You also have the very cool opportunity of upvoting questions that have already been submitted,
and by you upvoting the question, it gives us indication as to whether or not this is of interest to a larger number of individuals and
we'll try to go through the questions that are of most interest, to the most people,
as best we can. The other cool thing about it is you can also
vote down questions but we don't do this here, right? [LAUGHTER] It's technically possible but it's not cool.
So- so please remember that. And also our tech team is appreciating your stress testing our WiFi in the room.
I hope everybody will be able to connect, doing it before the queries burden as the quarter begins.
So, let's get started. Accessing course content, right?
So as we all know, our quarter begins next week. Next week is week one. The most important thing for you to do is to access your course website and identify,
the platform and how to access the lectures in the course.
Go to the SCPD website, then click on the My Stanford connection button login,
and as you complete your login process, you will get to you, essentially your dashboard where the class or classes you're taking will be listed, right?
That should provide information for you at the very least, to a- to our video platform.
Our video platform and video access where recorded lectures are hosted. Do not wait to receive a special invitation from anyone, right?
So, this is just like when you got your undergraduate degree or any other graduate degree, right? You're now students in university,
you're expected to find your classroom, even if it's a virtual classroom. Many teaching teams will send out the welcome email,
but it's your responsibility to go and find that information. I do want to mention that depending on the course that you are enrolled in,
you will access your course information either via a Canvas website. Canvas is a Learning Management System in use here,
or a website, or some other platform. That information is available to you after you log in.
For most classes that we offer here at SCPD, recorded lectures are also available in near
real time by logging into canvas.stanford.edu. You go to canvas.stanford.edu,
you use your student ID to sign in, you get your dashboard with a tile that you can click and access your class.
So, the nice thing about it is that because classes are streamed in near real time, if you know, for example,
that your first class is on Monday at 9:30 and your schedule is open at work, you can actually log into the system,
and you'll be able to watch that first lecture as it is given. Canvas is also the place where recording of
lectures and other sessions from the course will be kept throughout the quarter. So definitely check that out. Really easy to use.
We get fantastic reviews for that system. Contacts. Any questions you have about your course, about your class,
the best way to get an answer is simply to contact the teaching team, and how to contact the teaching team will be available on the class website.
Any other issues that are not related to the academic content or if you're not sure, please, please do not hesitate and contact our student and client services team.
We're here to support you especially during the first week of the quarter. So, the one thing we don't want you to do is,
you know, don't hesitate, right? Ask us those questions.
Exam Procedures. Very, very important and you'll notice the red font, right?
So, students in classes with in-class monitored exam must have an approved exam monitor.
Information about how to get that process started is on the exam section in my Stanford connection.
So just log in and understand the process, understand how it works.
The autumn exam monitor nomination due deadline is Monday, October 8th.
So, this is really- if there's one thing to take right is to make sure you understand the process, you know, who can be an exam monitor and you complete this process by October 8th.
Any delay in doing this, right? Increases the likelihood of
needless worrying about stuff not happening on time, right? So, please be sure to take that action item, that step.
Stanford Honor Code. What is it? The Stanford Honor Code is a set of standards that
establish the expectation for academic integrity required of all students, and you are now students in the university, right?
If you want to get- I highly recommend, Google search Stanford Honor Code, you will get to university website,
where all the policies are detailed. But in a nutshell, you're supposed to do your own work.
You're not supposed to help others with their work, and others are-
And vice-versa, right? So- so here are some violations that I think are interesting, right?
And I collected these from prior classes. The teaching team in your class will also have additions to this policy.
So, looking at previous years' homework solutions, right? Either official or written by another student,
discussing homework problem, right? So, individual assignments are to be completed individually.
Submitting malicious code, right? Not an honorable thing to do, it's a violation of the honor code. Don't do it.
Uploading your code, if you're dealing with computer code to a public repository like GitHub; that's a violation.
And we have the systems in place, right? So, [LAUGHTER] let's not and try and see if we have systems in place to identify these events.
I will say that the process is a serious process, a process of honor code violation.
It is a very fair process and in the few instances where we have been involved, we certainly notice that there is a
sincere effort on the part of the university to make sure that your side is heard. Know the policy.
Course Evaluations. There are two opportunities for you to give feedback. The first one will happen midquarter.
We will send to you via email the SCPD midquarter survey. It happens around week five.
That survey is for us to understand, to make sure that everything works, right? It is not a vehicle for you to ask questions of the teaching team,
and it's not a vehicle for you to ask questions that are timely, right? We receive hundreds of responses and while we read through all those responses,
if there's something timely there, that you need us to respond to, it might take us a couple of weeks, that's not the way to go.
The university end of quarter evaluation is available on the 10th and 11th week of the quarter.
Very important to complete that. You do not want to cause- incompletion of it to cause
any delay in you getting your grades at the end of the quarter. Important deadlines. Important deadlines.
First day of instruction is next week. The drop deadline is Friday, October 12th, before 5:00 PM, Pacific Time.
Withdrawals and grading basis changes, November 16; incomplete request, December seven.
Assignments and exam are subject to your class syllabus, right? So, [NOISE] you're all working professionals, most of you are.
However, work-related travel or heavy workload generally speaking is not a-
is not considered a sufficient justification for skipping a deadline, right? So, at the same time,
we know that life happens. When events outside your control happen
that might cause you to miss a deadline, [NOISE] be diligent and inform the teaching teams as early as you can,
and do not hesitate to involve the Student Client Services team also. The earlier we know of a challenge the earlier we have an opportunity to help.
The last one, the last item here I want to speak to is tuition reimbursement, right? Many of you will receive tuition reimbursement from your companies.
Some companies because autumn quarter ends, very near to the end of December,
end of the year. Some companies stop processing these requests, say on December 15th, right?
Your responsibility is to understand the policy at your company. Know if you have any deadlines
for submitting tuition reimbursement request in your company, and make sure that, you know, when will the grades be available.
In certain cases we can help you get your grades a few days earlier, but please, let us know about that in advance.
These are the important policies, right? [NOISE] All of it is on the website.
Thank you for listening as we review these. I hope you've been busily

think about what we covered, and I will now introduce my colleague, Pax Hehmeyer.
We'll also bring our panel of experts, and will take us through what we hope is the heart of the conversation tonight,
which is asking questions, right? [NOISE] Students, professor, and TA, Pax.
Okay. [NOISE] I'm Pax Hehmeyer, I am the Associate Director at SCPD,
and so it's my pleasure to introduce the panel tonight, which is made up of instructors and grad- and
students here at this part of the SCPD program. So, I'll just invite them to come up to the chairs up here front and center,
well, front and to the side, I suppose. And [LAUGHTER] I'll introduce them as we go through and then we'll come up with some questions and then at the end,
I'll come back to the questions that you'll be posting on poll everywhere and direct some of them to the panel here.

So, as his role is sort of, a lead TA, he oversaw a lot of logistics for SCPD's

And I want- I've got the microphone. So, we'll just pass it back and forth. And I want to start with just a high level question here for Nick Gonzales.
So, both of you have a lot of experience here working with students, helping them through.
So, Nick, we'll start with you just at a high level, what does it take to be a successful student here at SCPD?
What would be your high level advice to the students here tonight? Sure. Well, thanks for having me.
I think, you know, I've gotten the opportunity to have a lot of experience teaching SCPD classes,
which has been a lot of fun. And I think the biggest thing I would probably say is to engage with the teaching staff as much as you possibly can.
I think, you know, we certainly see from my personal experience and from other experiences from other TAs and instructors, you know,
the more that students on campus and remote engage with their teaching team, the better they do in the class because they get more responsive help.
They form relationships with their TAs, which is something that you can absolutely do on campus, but it's certainly harder to do when you're a remote student.
But, as you communicate with them, you can get better feedback. You can, you know, get- have more of a back and forth conversation about ways you can improve
and so that would be, kind of, my number one piece of feedback is the teaching team is, you know, for every team that I've been on,
has been extremely eager and, and interested to hear feedback from every SCPD student and want to engage with them as much as possible.
So, you know, I encourage you to take advantage of that. Before you pass on, just one question that's already come up maybe as a follow-up is,
who should students be reaching out to first? Is it the TA, the CA, the professor? Who's best to make that first outreach to and
how soon should they do that? Yeah. It's a great question. So, I think, certainly, there's a lot of benefit in reaching out in the first week or two for sure,
just to get some contact on the teaching team to kind of get your orientation. A lot of classes for SCPD organized the TA team to,
have certain SCPD students assigned to certain graders. For instance, that's a great person to reach out to because they're the ones
that are gonna be giving you feedback on ways to improve and then last but not least, some classes have specific SCPD TAs that they might make
available to you as well for office hours or other questions. So, it really depends on, kind of, the class organization and the class size.
But for the most part, there are usually multiple people that have different responsibilities in relation to you,
and it's definitely beneficial to reach out to all of them. Thank you, Nick. And Zahra, can you share some of your insight?
Hi. I'm Zahra and I'm very excited to be again, SCPD TA this quarter.
So as Nick said, I just want to add, one more thing is that
[NOISE] to be a successful SCPD student, I think it is important. In addition to try to connect to the TAs,
try to connect to other SCPD students. For CS229, in particular,
we have a site called Piazza. Make sure that
you log in to the Piazza very early in the quarter. This is like the most important
like question and answer source for on-campus student and remote students.
So, when you got a question, just make sure that this question is not already asked in Piazza.
And if it is a new for everyone, post it on Piazza. And also another good feature on the Piazza is that it helps you to find,
like good teammate for your class.
So, basically, from my experience, I was student here in Stanford.
If you want to get the best outcome of the Stanford courses,
especially in the CS department, is that you find the teammates
that have the same concern as you, working on the same assignment,
same like project that can help you, to have the better experience.
So, it's not like you sit alone at home and do your assignments only by yourself.
So, it's good to be in connection with the other student and, have their help.
So, try to be connected to the TAs and to the other students,
specifically SCPD, other SCPD students. That's fantastic advice.

and we use that avenue Piazza like she was mentioning before, and Skype or video chat.
So, that's my experience with it. Yeah, there's a Slack that I think a lot of SCPD students are on and then, there's also,

if you think back to your first quarter here with SCPD? I mean, what course were you taking, and you know,
what do you wish you had known before you began in the program? Yeah, so my first quarter with SCPD, I took,
I can't remember the exact course number, but it was client-side, web programming essentially.
And it was really good. I actually think for your first course, you might want to consider taking,
it was a lighter course, it was a 100-level course. And so, you might want to consider taking something like that to kind of gauge the workload and so on.
So, I I think that was really helpful not to start with, you know, a heavier course.
And just if I were to go back, one of the things would be, you know, in general, you got to- you have to think of all these courses and your SCPD kind
of career as more of a marathon rather than a sprint. So, you know, try to- if you take all the intense courses all at once, you know,
or try to take multiple courses in your first quarter or anything like that, you might, you know, get turned off from the entire program.
So, definitely pace yourself, take breaks in between quarters if you need it, and you know, just think about it as being,
a longer-term investment rather than just one-quarter investment. That's great. Colby, do you have,
anything that you would add to that? No, no. I, I agree with him completely about the longer-term investment.
These courses are very intense and the teaching team puts a lot of effort into making sure that it's really a unique experience for you.
So, you're not just going to be doing problems out of the back of the book, you'll be very engaged. So, I mean, I agree with him completely.
It is a marathon. Could you both maybe talk a little bit more about the kind of workload that you,
experienced and what your typical week like, is like as an SCPD student? Yes, so I'm taking one class or I'm fixing to start up one class right now,
but, I take one class a quarter. So, my workload, I dedicate probably about three days a week towards,
you know, just this class in the evenings or so. That means attending the teaching assistants' live Q and A sessions, that you can ask.
it's typically through Skype or some other method, and engaging with other SCPD students.
I've actually been on campus quite a few times. For my last class, I did a presentation here,
for my first class here. You know, I spent an entire month down here working on a robotics competition.
So, my workload is typically pretty heavy with SCPD. I'd say 20 to 30 hours a week is average,
sometimes heavier, depending on what classes you're taking. Okay. Yeah, I would say
it's very dependent on the class you take. I've had classes where there was 15 hours a week and I've had classes where I was above,
30 hours a week. The key thing I think, which was pointed out earlier is having a study group
probably like cuts your workload down significantly. I think my first few classes, I just tried to go it alone and you know,
just do it all by myself, and that probably added like ten hours a week to my workload. But it's
an investment of time especially if you're working. And the other thing is, if you
want to take classes, almost everybody I know is taking one class a quarter.
So, if you're considering taking more than one class a quarter, definitely like really strongly consider that decision and make sure you know what you're getting into before you do that.
That's great advice. I did two classes it sucked, so [LAUGHTER] I was here until like 3:00 AM for like multiple times a week.
So, yeah. So, I advise against it. Heard it here, you heard it here. Yeah. So maybe building on that, Zara,
could you talk about some of the common difficulties and struggles that you see SCPD students facing on your side?
Oh, yeah, sure. I think one of the most common problem is that the SCPD student start working on an assignments too late.
Start working on an assignment as soon as it is published and posted. Because if you just postpone doing the assignments on the weekend,
that's not how it works, right? So, on weekends you see some problem, you post on Piazza,
it takes some time for the teaching staff because they are on the weekends too, right? So, you should expect some delays.
And then, you would, I mean, there are other SCPD might complain that "Hey,
it's like, let's say, five hours that I posted my question, why I didn't get my- any answer yet?"
So, try to start working on the assignment as early as it is published.
And then the other thing, as they mentioned, so I was TA for 229 and 230.
Also I took 221 and other CS courses. They're not easy courses.
They are intense. Be prepared for them. So, we had like a ton of emails
like three weeks before finals, saying that, "Hey, I didn't expect this workload from these courses.
May I request incomplete? May I drop the course?"
This is not something that usually happen. So, if you think you cannot
dedicate enough time to this course, just reconsider your decision for taking this course.
We have, as far as I know, we have a long wait list for the students wants to take this course and,
they can't be enrolled. So, if you think you cannot dedicate enough time for these intense courses,
reconsider your decision. Thank you. Tushar did you wanna-
I'm sorry. Just so it's not all, you know, [LAUGHTER] just really doom and gloom. [LAUGHTER] I think there's definitely, like,
a rhythm and it might take you til like your second or third quarter to hit that rhythm. But, you know, your first quarter you're going to
be trying to figure out how to balance like, you know, what time do I watch the lectures on. Do I watch it after dinner? Do I watch on the weekends?
And you're going to be trying to figure out how like, you know, should I start the assignments early or should I wait till, you know, later or how long does it take?
By the time I maybe hit my third course or my fourth course, I was starting to get into this rhythm, and when you get into that rhythm,
like, it makes it a lot easier. Because you know that, okay the lecture is published Tuesday I have to set aside some time to, like, watch it Tuesday night.
